1890-2012 The Tamiment Library and Robert F. Wagner Labor Archives Collection of Labor Movement Serials groups 2,116 titles published between 1891 and 2012 mainly chronicling the labor movement in the 20th century, originally received by the Tamiment Library through subscriptions, donations, and as part of archival collections. The majority of the collection consists of incomplete runs of newspapers, newsletters, bulletins, and mailings distributed by unions, national and local chapters of labor organizations, rank and file groups, government agencies, and advocacy groups. The serials document the activities of individual unions and organizations as well as the trajectory of the labor movement more broadly, with discussions on labor law and government policy, relationships and solidarity between affinity groups, and the concerns of particular constituencies of workers. Serials in this collection range from official publications and proceedings regularly distributed by large, AFL-CIO-affiliated organizations to pamphlets and printed matter informally circulated by organizers to announce meetings and actions. In addition to serials chronicling the labor movement in the United States, there are significant quantities of material relating to labor conditions in Europe and Canada. Materials primarily in English, with some publications in Spanish, Swedish, German, French, Polish, Italian, Yiddish, and Chinese. Materials are stored offsite and advance notice is required for use. Please contact tamiment.wagner@nyu.edu at least two business days prior to your research visit to coordinate access.
Conditions Governing Access
Open to users without restriction.
Immediate Source of Acquisition
This collection combines serials relating to the labor movement drawn from two discrete groups of material held by the Tamiment Library. The first was a partially inventoried backlog of serials, received by the library through donations, subscriptions, and in archival collections. The second group consisted of around 1,700 serials, newspapers, and magazines, organized by title as an artificial collection, referred to as Periodicals.001 or Boxed Newspapers. This material was combined, inventoried, and arranged and described in subject-based categories in 2017.
Arrangement
This collection imposes an artificial arrangement on a range of disparate material separated from the order in which it was originally received at Tamiment Library. The material is separated into five series, dividing serials into groups of topically similar material. The first series largely collects serials issued by labor unions, grouping this material into 12 narrower subseries, according to a union's trade or constituency. The remaining series collect concentrations of similar types of material, for example labor newspapers, or material originating from outside the United States. Within each series, material is arranged at the file level, in alphabetical order by publishing organization. Where possible issues of each publication are organized chronologically, grouped by year. Each title is listed alongside its publishing organization and city of origin, where this information is available.
Physical Characteristics and Technical Requirements
Due to the fragile nature of certain original materials, researchers may be required to consult microfilm copies, preservation photocopies, or digital images of material in this collection.
Preferred Citation
Identification of item, date; Tamiment Library and Robert F. Wagner Labor Archives Collection of Labor Movement Serials; WAG.345; box number; folder number; Tamiment Library/Robert F. Wagner Labor Archives, New York University.
Processing Information
The material in this collection was assembled from various backlogs of uncataloged material held by the Tamiment Library. This material was inventoried, separated according to its subject matter, and arranged in a series of subject-based artificial collections. Accumulations of similar material relating to the labor movement were identified -- volumes of daily labor newspapers; serials and pamphlets issued by labor research organizations -- informing five series of material, grouping material by genre (Labor News), provenance (International Labor Organizations), or topic (Labow Law; Labor Research). A taxonomy used within the Tamiment Library, delineating affinities between different industries and unions in detail, was used to structure the 12 subseries of Series I. Within each series, serials are arranged alphabetically by publishing organization, with titles generally listed alongside their publishing organization and place of publication.
Scope and Contents
The Tamiment Library and Robert F. Wagner Labor Archives Collection of Labor Movement Serials groups 2,116 titles published between 1891 and 2012 mainly chronicling the labor movement in the 20th century, originally received by the Tamiment Library through subscriptions, donations, and as part of archival collections.
The majority of the collection consists of incomplete runs of newspapers, newsletters, bulletins, and mailings distributed by unions, national and local chapters of labor organizations, rank and file groups, government agencies, and advocacy groups. The serials document the activities of individual unions and organizations -- meetings, elections, appointments, negotiations -- as well as the fluctuating trajectories of the labor movement more broadly, with discussions on labor law and government policy, relationships and solidarity between affinity groups, and the concerns of particular constituencies of workers. Serials in this collection range from official publications and conference proceedings regularly distributed by large, AFL-CIO-affiliated organizations to pamphlets and printed matter informally circulated by organizers to announce meetings and actions. Among the larger organizations represented in this collection are the Amalgamated Clothing Workers of America; the Communication Workers of America; the American Federation of Teachers; the International Brotherhood of Teamsters; and Teamsters for a Democratic Union, as well as prominent labor coalitions in New York State like the United Federation of Teachers and the New York City Central Labor Council. Notable titles include American Postal Worker; Labor Chronicle; United Labor Action; United Teacher; Working Teamster; The NMU Pilot; Solidarity, issued by the Labor Committee of the New York Students for a Democratic Society; and the Philadelphia Workers' Organizing Committee's Organizer.
The trades and professions represented in this collection form a comprehensive cross-section of organized labor in the 20th century, encompassing bulletins from unions and rank and file groups representing the building trades, communications workers, public employees, transport employee unions, education and entertainment unions, farmworkers and longshoremen, retail and service workers, and coalitions representing demographics working across different sectors, for example the Jewish Labor Committee.
In addition to the material documenting the activities of unions in America, the collection also includes a series dedicated to labor research and history, and a collection of trade journals and labor newspapers. Around 300 titles originate from outside the United States, with significant quantities of Canadian and European publications, often representing international bodies or research groups discussing labor policy. No complete runs of publications are contained herein, and generally only a handful of issues of each publication are held.
Conditions Governing Use
Because of the assembled nature of this collection, copyright status varies across the collection. Copyright is assumed to be held by the original creator of individual items in the collection; these items are expected to pass into the public domain 120 years after their creation. Repository is not authorized to grant permission to publish or reproduce materials from this collection.
Existence and Location of Copies
In some instances researchers may be required to consult microfilm copies of material held in this collection. Information on microfilm copies is included below each title listing.
Related Materials
For more publications on the AFL-CIO and affiliated organizations, see the Tamiment Library & Robert F. Wagner Labor Archives Collection of AFL-CIO Serials, WAG.362.

Series I: Labor unions and organizations72.1 Linear Feetin 19 record cartons, 29 manuscript boxes, 2 half manuscript boxes, and 152 flat boxes1890-2012
Scope and Contents
This series collects 1,723 publications -- serials, journals, magazines, newsletters, newspapers, bulletins, pamphlets -- issued by labor unions and other related organizations. The majority of the series collects weekly or monthly bulletins distributed by local chapters of unions documenting local activities, wider national efforts, and the lives of union members.
Arrangement
The material in this series is divided into 12 subseries: Subseries I.A: Building Trades; Subseries I.B: Communication Workers; Subseries I.C: Constituency Groups; Subseries I.D: Co-operatives; Subseries I.E: Education Workers; Subseries I.F: Entertainment; Subseries I.G: Farmworkers and Agricultural Unions; Subseries I.H: Maritime Workers; Subseries I.I: Labor Coalitions and Organizations; Subseries I.J: Public Employees; Subseries I.K: Retail and Service Workers; and Subseries I.L: Transportation Workers. These series group together material issued by organizations operating in similar trades -- educators; entertainment workers; public employees -- or, in the case of Series I, Subseries C, group organizations uniting members around identity or common interest. A taxonomy used within Tamiment Library to structure access to its collections, delineating affinities between different industries and unions in detail, was adapted to structure the 12 subseries of Series I.Subseries I.A: Building Trades12 Linear Feetin 3 record cartons, 13 manuscript boxes, 1 half manuscript box, and 17 flat boxes1918-2004
Scope and Contents
This series collects publications issued by construction and building trades unions, mainly through the 20th century. Large organizations of painters, molders, miners, chemical workers, and engineers -- including the American Federation of Technical Engineers, and the United Steelworkers of America -- are represented at both the national and local level. Smaller organizations and rank and file groups are represented by newsletters circulated to raise awareness around topics including health issues among miners (Miner's Voice; Progressive Miner; Straight Track); Scope and Contents
Uniting telephone workers, mail carriers, typographic and print unions, and chapters of the Newspaper Guild, this series assembles serials issued by communications workers, with the majority of titles dating between 1950-1990. Around 150 newsletters from individual chapters of the Communications Workers of America, mainly dating from the 1980s, document a range of local union activities across the United States. Scope and Contents
This series collects newsletters and serials issued by organizations representing demographic groups working across different industries, including publications issued by Asian-American organizations and staff groups (Asian Americans for Equal Employment; Chinese Staff and Workers Association); African-American workers (the Black Workers Congress; Coalition of Revolutionary Black Workers; Coalition of Black Trade Unionists); religious organizations (The Workmen's Circle; Histradut); and women's groups (Non-Traditional Employment for Women; Women for Economic Justice; Union Women's Alliance to Gain Equality). Featuring many organizations based in New York City, and largely dating from the 1970s to the 1990s, publications often combine local community news with writing around labor activism, detailing the living and working conditions of factory workers, restaurant staff, and sleeping car porters, among others.Update on Kenya : African-American Labor Center, Washington, DCcuid1016919932721Update on Malawi : African-American Labor Center, Washington, DCcuid1017019932722WomeNews : AFTRA National Women's Committee, Los Angeles, CAcuid1017119752723A.S.U. Due to the fragile condition of this material, access may be supervised or restricted.Subseries I.I: Labor Coalitions and Organizations19.8 Linear Feetin 3 record cartons, 16 manuscript boxes, and 38 flat boxes1890-2012
Scope and Contents
This series collects uncataloged serials and newsletters published by a variety of labor coalitions, advocacy groups, research institutions, professional associations, and political organizations. Formed around common interest groups, a full range of labor causes are detailed in bulletins, newspapers, and circulars: the rights of women in the workplace (various publications issued by the Coalition of Labor Union Women and New York Women's Trade Union); benefit and pension updates for workers (Employee Benefits Digest; Labor News for Working Families; Westchester 60 Plus); and activism around unemployment and working conditions (newsletters issued by Jobs With Justice; Rhode Island Workers Association Organizing Center; and the Trade Union League). Issuing organizations range from large coalitions (Jewish Labor Committee; New York City Central Labor Council; Philadelphia Workers' Organizing Committee) to smaller bodies and rank and file groups providing information for workers exposed to asbestos (Abestos Update).Labor Review : "Published in the interest of Organized Labor", Troy, NYcuid1050519401561El Obrero : AFL-CIO, Mexico, Mexicocuid1050619631411Noticiero Obrero Norteamericano : AFL-CIO, Washington, DCcuid105071963, 19771736AFL-CIO Noticiero del Movimiento Sindical Libre : AFL-CIO - Departmento de Asuntos Internacionales, Washington, DCcuid10508197717224S.T.I.R. Scope and Contents
This series collects various uncataloged serials and newsletters mainly issued by large national organizations including the American Federation of State, County and Municipal Employees; Civil Service Employees Association; Civil Service Employees Association; District Council 1707 Shop Stewards; New York State Department of Labor; and New York State School of Industrial and Labor Relations at Cornell University. Weekly and monthly newsletters document union advocacy at a national scale, providing significant coverage of changes in labor law -- collective bargaining; retiree rights; strike actions -- as well as documenting the day-to-day circumstances of particular unions, for example the election of union representatives, and divisions between organizations and rank and file groups.Princeton University Scope and Contents
The serials in this series document the activities of unions of clothing workers, retail staff, hospital housestaff, and hotel and food service employees. Among the publishing organizations represented are large, national unions including the Amalgamated Clothing and Textile Workers Union and International Ladies' Garment Workers' Union. The series contains newspapers and newsletters documenting textile work in and around New York throughout the 20th Century, including serials aimed at younger readers -- the International Ladies' Garment Workers' Union's Student Magazine -- and three variants of the International Ladies' Garment Workers' Union's newspaper Justice: the Italian-language Giustizia, the Yiddish-language Gerechtigkeit, and the Spanish-language Justicia).Union Builder : Advancecuid1098219374950New York Hotel-Motel Trades Council : AFL-CIO196419811Nor'easter : Amalgamated Northeast Regional Joint Board, UNITE, New York, NYcuid1098319994951Union Leader : Amalgamated Association of Street Electric Railway and Motor Coach Employees, Chicago, ILcuid109841942601Actor Unity : Amalgamated Clothing and Textile Organization of Retirees, New York, NYcuid1098519894952ACTWU Action : Amalgamated Clothing and Textile Workers Union, AFL-CIO, CLC19771971ACTWU Labor : Amalgamated Clothing and Textile Workers Union, AFL-CIO, CLC, New York, NYcuid1098619764953ACTWU Songbook : Amalgamated Clothing and Textile Workers Union, AFL-CIO, CLC, New York, NYcuid10987circa 1970s4954How the Union Works : Amalgamated Clothing and Textile Workers Union, AFL-CIO, CLC, New York, NYcuid10988circa 1970s4948J.P. Scope and Contents
This series contains publications issued by national and local unions of transit workers, including a significant number of titles issued by Teamster organizations, encompassing local and rank and file chapters of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters and Teamsters for a Democratic Union. Several other national unions -- Retail, Wholesale & Department Store Union; Transport Workers Union of America; United Auto Workers -- are represented, often by subsidiary groups like Auto Workers United to Fight.Contact : Air Transport Local 501, TWU-CIO, Jackson Heights, NYcuid111761946-19487333Wing Ways : Air Transport Local 501, TWU-CIO, LaGuardia Field, NYcuid111771947-19487334Airliner : Airline Employees' Local 508, TWU-CIO, LaGuardia Field, NYcuid1117819477335Union Leader : Amalgamated Association of Street Electric Railway and Motor Coach Employees, Chicago, IL19512135726 Express : Amalgamated Transit Union - Division 726, Staten Island, NYcuid111791990-1991, 19941163Rank-N-File : Amalgamated UAW Local 893, Marshalltown, IAcuid1118019937336Taxi News : Arthur T. Scope and Contents
This series collects various uncataloged serials and publications documenting the labor movement outside of the United States. The series contains significant quantities of material documenting unionization in Canada -- organizations include the Canadian Labour Congress; Canadian Union of Public Employees; and the Co-Operative Union of Canada -- as well as in Europe. The series also contains reports and publications issued by international bodies concerning globalization, environmental regulation, and regionally specific elements of the labor movement, specifically in Vietnam (Vietnamese Trade Unions); Japan ("Problems and Difficulties" of Japanese Workers Today: Towards the Extraction of Needs); the United Kingdom (Future of British Agriculture).Class Struggle and the Strike (United States) : A. Scope and Contents
This series collects a variety of serials and publications largely issued by institutions specializing in labor research and history. These include newsletters and catalogs produced by the George Meany Center for Labor Studies and the School of Industrial and Labor Relations, as well as material published by smaller organizations like the American Labor Museum, Ozarks' Labor Union Archive, and New England Free Press. Other titles include independently produced reports on topics including collective bargaining, outsourcing in manufacturing, and general strikes in France; catalogues rounding up labor titles distributed by Greenwood Press and Charles H. Kerr & Co; and a journal of new workplace technology, Black Chip.100th Anniversary Journal - Haymarket - May Day - The Struggle for the Eight Hour Day : 100th Anniversary Committee, New York, NYcuid964019861611But What About the Workers? : Advocators, Detroit, MIcuid964119731612Annual Report of the American Labor Education Service, Inc. : American Labor Education Service, New York, NYcuid964219541613American Labor Museum Newsletter : American Labor Museum, Haledon, NJcuid96431983, 1987, 1989, 1990, 1995, 1996, 1998, 2000, 2001, 2004, 20051614Slice of the Earth : American Labor Museum, Haledon, NJcuid964419831615Fifteenth Annual Sol Stetin Awards Dinner Honoring Pete Seeger and John Tesaro : American Labor Museum Botto House National Landmark, Haledon, NJcuid964519971616ASHP News : American Social History Project, New York, NYcuid964619961617Institute for Labor Studies Survey : Appalachian Center West Virginia University, Morgantown, WVcuid9647197017252Beaver Valley Labor History Journal : Beaver Valley Labor History Society, Alquippa, PAcuid96481979-1980834Canadian Mining Review : Canadian Mining Review, Toronto, Canadacuid96491947872American Labor : ComCor, Inc.cuid9650196816212ILR Labor Advance : Cornell University ILR School, New York, NYcuid965120081618The Italian Labor Movement : Cornell University Press, Ithaca, New Yorkcuid965219571619Labor Movement in the United States : Department of Public Instruction, Harrisburg, PAcuid9653196316110Union Town -
